verb.description: Provide or give (a service, help, etc.)
examples: money serves as a reward for services rendered
Mrs. Evans would render assistance to those she thought were in real need

verb.description: Cause to be or become; make.
examples: the rains rendered his escape impossible
the eyes and the cheeks are exceptionally well rendered

verb.description: Covertly send (a foreign criminal or terrorist suspect) for interrogation abroad; subject to extraordinary rendition.

examples: the fat was being cut up and rendered for lard

verb.description: Cover (stone or brick) with a coat of plaster.
examples: external walls will be rendered and tiled

noun.description: A first coat of plaster applied to a brick or stone surface.

origin: Late Middle English: from Old French rendre, from an alteration of Latin reddere give back, from re- back + dare give. The earliest senses were recite, translate, and give back (hence represent and perform); hand over (hence give help and submit for consideration); cause to be; and melt down.
